title: Teaching
text:
I currently teach courses in causal inference (MF9570), survival analysis (e.g. MF9510), and introductory statistics (e.g. MF9130), mainly at the PhD program at the Faculty of Medicine, University of Oslo.
In April 2024 I held an online ISCB course in biostatistics together with Ruth Keogh on causal inference for time-to-event outcomes with practical applications in R.

title: Research
text:
My main research interests are causal inference and time-to-event analysis. In particular, I have worked on methods for estimating the effects of time-varying treatments on survival outcomes under time-dependent confounding and multi-state modelling of event history data. I also have an interest in studies of infectious diseases, and have done some work on topics such as vaccine effectiveness, excess mortality, infectious disease surveillance and infectious disease modelling.
I am interested in applications using both randomised and observational data, and in particular event history outcomes constructed using data from linked clinical and population-wide registries. I am currently involved in various collaborative projects, e.g. on the effects of rehabilitation and pain medication on patient outcomes after traumatic injury with researchers at the Oslo University Hospital, and on the effects of rehabilitation and workplace initiatives on long-term sick leave and work-related outcomes with researchers at the National Institute of Occupational Health in Norway. I am currently the PI of projects with funding from the Institute of Basic Medical Sciences, University of Oslo, and from the Research Council of Norway.
See my Google Scholar profile for publications.

title: Jon Michael Gran
text:
I am a professor of biostatistics at Oslo Centre of Biostatistics and Epidemiology, Department of Biostatistics, University of Oslo, working on causal inference and survival/event history analysis.
Currently I also have a 20% position at the Department of Method Development and Analytics, Division of Infection Control and Environmental Health, Norwegian Institute of Public Health, and I am an associate editor in Biometrika.
See also my personal web pages at the University of Oslo and the web pages of our causal inference and survival analysis group.
